titlestmt.title: SSSC 22: He Who Carries the Old Woman
titlestmt.author: Sakewew

bibl.title: Sacred Stories of the Sweet Grass Cree

encodingdesc.p: This electronic document is oriented more toward representing those features that seem most likely to be relevant for grammatical analyses, rather than toward faithfully representing all the information available in the book.

list.item: 2014 06 10; KR; UTF-8, paragraph and sentence numbering, smart-quotes in English translations

body.head: Sacred Stories 22: He Who Carried the Old Woman

p.seg: kîtahtawê nistiwak ayîsiyiniwak , nîso nâpêwak . Once upon a time there were three people, two men and one woman, two men.
ôhi nâpêwa osîmiw aw îskwêw . The men were the younger brothers of the woman.
êkwah pêyak namoy âtoskêw osîmimâw . The youngest one did not work.
misâskwat otinam ; ayâw , ê-saskahohtêt ohci . He took a stick of saskatoon willow; he kept it, walking with it as a cane.
êkwah ostêsa mâciyiwa , mîciwin êh-tôtamâkocik . His elder brother hunted, providing them with food.

kîtahtawê awa nâpêw ostêsimâw , mistah êh-ayâcik mîciwin ,
hâ , nisîm , mahtih nka-ntonawâw awiyak kit-ôwîstâwiyahk , kimisinaw kit-ônâpêmit . Then at one time, when they had a big supply of food, the elder man said, “Well now, brother, suppose I look for someone to be our brother-in-law, so that our sister may have a husband.

seg.q: êwako owîstâwiyahko , namoya kika-nêpêwisinânaw , nâpêw ôtah ayâci .
seg.gloss: If we have him for brother-in-law, we shall not be embarrassed, when a man is here.”
seg.note: LB: On account of the brother-and-sister tabu; the sister's husband would make communication possible.

p.seg: êhag , itik . “Very well,” the other answered.
kîtahtawê sipwêhtêw , êh-pa-pmohtêt . Presently he set out and tramped along.
pêyakwâw ê-kîh-nipât , wâpahtam mîkiwâhp . After one night on the way, he saw a tipi.
âpihtâ-kîsikâhk itskwâstawêstêyiw . It stood with the door facing the direction of noon.

êkosi pôtih kâ-wâpamât kâhkâkiwa êh-okâhkwâskwahikaniyit . Then as he looked, he beheld a crow holding together the tips of the tent-poles. LB on {êh-okâhkwâskwahikaniyit}: English-speaking informants could not tell what {kâhkwâskwahikan} was. Literally, it is “thing for tightening (?) sticks.”
pôtih êh-otihtahk , kâ-kitôwiyit ôhi k-âkociniyit mîkiwâhpihk . When he came there, that creature at the top of the tent gave a call. Is kitowiyit relational, or just 'kitoyit'?
tawâw ! itik . “Come in!” it called to him.
pîhtokêw . He entered.
kîh-pêyakoyiwa nâpêwa . There was a man all alone.
pôtih êh-kîsi-mîcisot , nâpêwa kâ-takosiniyit , kotakah oskinîkiwa . When he had eaten, a man arrived, another youth.

êkwah ômis îtwêw :
kêkway êh-papâ-nâtaman , kâ-papâmohtêyan ? itik . He said, “What are you seeking, that you wander about?” he asked him.

seg.q: nka-miyâw nimisah , êh-itêyimitân , ê-nayêhtawiyân , êkâ wîhkâc êh-pîkiskwêt nimis , k-ôh-pê-miyitân .
seg.gloss: ‘I shall give him my elder sister,’ is my thought, concerning you, for I am inconvenienced by my sister's never speaking; that is why I have come to give her to you.”
seg.note: LB: On account of the brother-and-sister tabu.

p.seg: wiya mâka nahâ nisîm mâskôc ta-têpêyimôw , itik . but perhaps my younger brother right here will like the idea,” he told him.

seg.q: hâ , osâm nam êskwa nnihtâh-nipahtân kêkway , ta-kîh-wîwiyân wâwis niya ; ahpôh kiya kêkway kinihtâ-nipahtân , êkâ tiyêpêyimoyin .
seg.gloss: “Oh, as yet I am not good enough at killing things, to be able to marry, I above all, seeing that even you, who are good at killing things, do not like the idea.”

p.seg: ahahêy ! itwêw aw ostêsimâw ; “Dear me!” said the elder;

seg.q: ôtah kisiwâk wîkiwak nisîmak ê-nîsicik , pêyak nistês , êh-nêwicik êwakonik , nisto osîma êh-pamihikot .
seg.gloss: “Near by here live three of my younger brothers and one elder brother, four of them; his three younger brothers take care of him.
seg.note: LB on {ê-nîsicik}: He means {ê-nisticik}, and I have so translated. Informant is given to slips of the tongue as regards numbers and opposites.

p.seg: osâm nihtâh-nipahtâwak kêkway êyakonik , itik ; They are very good at killing game,” he told him;
mâskôc pêyak kita-têpêyimôw , itik . Perhaps one of them will take to the idea,” he told him.
itohtêw . He went there.
pôtih ê-sâkêwêt ôm êspatinâyik , wâpahtam mîkiwâhp . As he came over the crest of the hill, there he saw a tipi.
pôtih kâhkwâskwahikanah wâpamêw , ôhôwa , êsay kâ-kitoyit . He saw what held the tips of the tent poles together, an owl, which already was giving its call.
itohtêw . He went there.

mayaw êy-otihtahk ,
tawâw , wêskinîkiyan ! itâw . Just as he reached the place, “Come in, young man!” he was told. CHECK weskinikiyan
êkosi itohtêw . So he went there.
pîhtokêw . He entered.
asamâw . He was given food.
ê-kîsi-mîcisot , ist ôskinîkiwa pîhtokêyiwa . When he had eaten, look you, a young man came into the tent.
pîhtatwânah ah-akotêyiwa . He hung up some quivers.
hâw , tânisi êtiskâyan , ôma kâ-pêh-itohtêyan ôtah ? itwêw aw ostêsimâw . “Hello, what is your errand, that you come here like this?” asked the eldest of his brothers. IC of atoskê ?

ômis itêw :
âh , nimis êh-pê-miyitakok pêyak . He told him, “Oh, it is that I have come to give one of you my sister, elder than I.”

seg.gloss: “As for me, I am only give food by my younger brothers.
I am no good at killing any kind of game.

p.seg: namoya ta-kî-wîcêwak iskwêw , itwêw ; I could not have a wife,” he told him;

êkwah ,
hâw , nisîmitik , nikotwâw pêyak itohtêk kiyawâw ! and then, “Now, brothers, some one of you go there!”

itik :
hâh , iyika mâ cêskwah kêkway nihtâh-nipahtâyâhk ! They answered him, “Ho, as if we were any good as yet at killing game!
namoya niya nka-kê-itohtân , itwêwak kahkiyaw . I shall not be able to go there,” said all of them.

seg.q: ahêy , wêskinîkiyan ! ôma k-ôsêhcâk awasâyihk êkotah wîkiw nôhtâwiy .
seg.gloss: “Dear me, young man! At the other side of the hill lives my father.

p.seg: mâwacih wêwostêsimâwiyit okosisah nêwo wîkimêw , êkâ cêskwah êh-wîwicik êwakonik nisîminânak , êkwah nîso oskinîkiskwêwak nisîminânak , itêw ; He lives with his four eldest sons, and these our elder brothers are not yet married; nor are the two young women, our younger sisters,” he told him;

seg.gloss: “Go there.

p.seg: mâskôc nôhtâwiy wîh-miyikoyêkoh otawâsimisah nisto , nîsw îskwêwa êkwah pêyak nâpêw , wîh-miyisk nôhtâwiy , itêw . Perhaps my father will give you three of his children, two women and one man, if my father wishes to give them to you,” he told him.
êkosi tâpwê wayawîw . Accordingly, he left the tent.
iyâyaw êkotê itohtêw kâ-kiskinôhamâht itêh . Eagerly he went to the place that had been indicated to him.

êkwah êy-ati-sâkêwêt , pôtih tâpwê mîkiwâhp wâpahtam âpihtâ-kîsikâhk êh-itiskwâstawêstêyik . And as on his way he came over the crest of a hill, there really he saw a tipi that stood with its doorway toward noon.
êkwah mayaw ê-wâpahtahk , wâpamik kâhkwâskwahikanah , kihiwa . As soon as he saw it, he was seen by the creature which held together the tips of the tent-poles, an eagle.
sêmâk kitôw awa kihiw . At once the eagle gave its cry.
takohtêw mîkiwâhpihk . He reached the tipi.
hâw , tawâw ! itâw . “Ho, come in!” he was told.
pîhtokêw . He entered.

awîn ôhi , kisêyiniwa , nôtokêsiwa , namwâc awiya wâpamêw , nêyêstaw itah êh-ohtapiyit omatôwahk , oma nôhtapiwin êkotôwahk ayihtahk ,
hâw , tawâw ! k-êtiht . Whom did he see but an old man and an old woman, and no one else he saw but them, sitting alone on a thing like this blanket, like this on which I am sitting now; and, “Come in!” he was told. CHECK ?? ay-ihtâ -hk (vai ‘exist’)?

ê-kîh-pîhtokêt ,
hâw , nôtokêsiw , asam ! ta-mîcisôw ! itâw . When he had come in, “Now, old woman, give him food! Let him eat!” was said about him.
ha , kêtahtawê asamâw . In due time he was given food.
ê-kîsi-mîcisot , kâ-pê-tatwêwitamiyit , pê-pâ-pîkiskwêyit iskwêwa . When he had eaten, suddenly there came some people with loud noise, two women, talking both at once.
piyê-pîhtokêyit , awîn ôhi , oskinîkiskwêwa . When they had come in, he saw that they were young girls.
ê-kîsi-nahapicik , kotakak mîna piyê-pîhtokêcik nêwo nâpêwak . When they had taken their seats, some more people came in, four men.

êkwah ômis îtik :
hâw , wêskinîkiyan , tânisiw ôma k-ôh-pê-ay-itohtêyan ? itwêw awa kisêyiniw ; Then the other said to him, “Now then, young man, how is it you have come tramping all the way here?” asked the old man;

seg.gloss: “Have you come to be with my children here?”

p.seg: êhag , itêw . “Yes,” he answered him.

seg.gloss: “But what is the aim of your wandering about?”

seg.q:
â , êyakonik kitawâsimisak ,
maht êkotah itohtê , êh-isicik .
seg.gloss: “Oh, because those children of yours told me, ‘You had better go there.’

seg.q: ê-nayêhtawiyâhk nimisinân , pikoh ê-wîcêwâyâhk , êkâ wîhkâc êh-pîkiskwêt nimis , êkwah pêyak nisîm oskinîkiw , anohc êw-ohci-wîcêwâyâhk .
seg.gloss: The fact is, we are in a difficult position with our elder sister, because we are alone with her, so that my sister never speaks; that is, I and my one younger brother, a young man, we are alone with her now.

seg.q: mâskôc pêyak kik-ôwîstâwin êkota ; nôhtâwiy ta-sîhkimêw tawâsimisah , êh-itwêt awa kikosis , kâ-kîh-pê-otihtitakok .
seg.gloss: ‘Perhaps you will find a brother-in-law in one of them there; my father will urge his children,’ said your son, and that is why I have come to you.”

seg.q: hâw , wêskinîkiyan , ôki ntawâsimisak iskwêwak nam êskwa nihtâwikwâsiwak , ta-kîh-onâpêmicik , mêkwâc kaskikwâsôwin êh-nôcihtâcik .
seg.gloss: “Well now, young man, these women children of mine have not yet learned to sew, so that they could take a man; in fact, they are even now engaged in learning to sew.

p.seg: hâw , êkos îsi nama kikê-miyitin , itik ; Well, so I cannot give them to you,” he told him;
hâw , kiyawâw , ntawâsimisitik , pêyak kit-êtohtêw , itêw ôhi nâpêwa nêwo . “Now then, as for you, my children, let one of you go there,” he said to those four men.

pikw ânah ,
cê ! êkâ mâ cêskwa ê-nôhtê-wîwiyân niya mina ! itik kahkiyaw ôhi nâpêwa . Each and every one, “Nonsense! I too am a long ways from wanting to marry just now!” all those men said to him.

seg.q: hê ê ay , wêskinîkiyin ! ayis nama tâpwêhtamwak tawâsimisak .
seg.gloss: “Dear me, young man! You see that my children will not hear of it.
You had best turn back from here and go home.

p.seg: aw , êkâh tâpwêhtamani , têpiyâhk ôtêh isi êkâ wiya itohtêh , itik . If you will not do that, at least do not go in this direction here,” he told him.
êkos îsi wayawîw . So he left the tipi.
ôma itêh kâ-kitahamâht , êkotê itohtêw . He went in the direction against which he had been warned.
pôtih êh-ati-pa-pmohtêt êh-osêhcâyik , ê-sâkêwêt , pôtih ka-wâpahtahk wistêpahkwayikamik . As he tramped along and came over the crest of a hill, there he saw a little lodge of smoked leather.
itohtêw . He went there.
iskwâhtêmihk êh-ihtât , ispimihk itâpiw apasôhk : pôtih apisîs kâ-pimâpahtêyik . As he stood in the doorway, he looked up at the tips of the lodge-poles: he saw a little smoke coming forth.
êkosi mwêhci ê-wîh-pîhtokêt , êh-paspâpit , awîn ôhi , mitoni nôtokêsiwah . Just as he was about to enter, as he peeked in, whom did he see, but a very old woman?
ômisi kîh-tôtamiyiwa , êh-nôhtê êh-nipahâyit otihkomiyiwa . [no translation]
ohcikwanihk ayiwakês môhkitapiw awa nôtokêsiw . [no translation]
êkosi asêhtêw aw ôskinîkiw . [no translation]

êh-iy-asêhtêt , nahikohtâkanêmôw ,
khhr ! êh-itwêt , [no translation]
awa nôtokêsiw ômisi kita-tôtam ; oskotâkay ta-yâsêkinam , êh-itêyihtahk aw ôskinîkiw . [no translation]
ayiwâkês iskonamiyiwa oskotâkayiwa . [no translation]
tawâw mâka , nôsisê ! itêw . But do come in, grandchild!” she said to him.

seg.gloss: “Well, at any rate she is an old woman.

p.seg: ta-yâsêkinam oskotâkay , itêyihtam . [no translation],” he thought.
pîhtokêw . He went in.
kwêskipayihôw awa nôtokêsiw . The old woman turned to face him.
kêkway ê-papâ-nâtaman ? itêw . “What are you going about for?” she asked him.
êh , nâpêw ê-papâ-ntonawak , kit-ôwîstâwiyân , itik . “I am going about looking for a man to be my brother-in-law,” he told her.
âta cî kikî-wâpamâwak aw ôtah kâ-wîkit nimanâcimâkan ? itik . “But have you seen my father-in-law who lives close by?” she asked him.

seg.gloss: “Yes.”
“Have you a wife?”
“No.”
“But have you seen my sisters-in-law?”
“Yes.”
“They are the ones I am teaching to sew.

p.seg: nihtâwikwâsotwâwi , iyikohk kit-ônâpêmicik , itêw ; As soon as they are good at sewing, they are to take husbands,” she told him;
niya nôcihkawin , itwêw awa nôtokêsiw . “I am the one for you to woo,” said the little old woman.
âh , osâm kinôtokêwin , nôhkô , itêw . “Oh, you are too old, grandmother,” he answered her.

seg.gloss: “Why! So now for the first time a mortal man rejects me!

seg.q: kahkiyaw aniki kâ-pêw-otihtacik , nnâpêmak aniki , êkâ kâ-tâpwêhtaman ta-wîkimiyan !
seg.gloss: All those whom you saw on your way here are my husbands, and here you refuse to marry me!”
“Oh, grandmother, you are too old!”

p.seg: êkosi ati-pasikôw , êkos êh-itât , He rose to his feet as he said this to her.

kwâskwêpayihôw awa nôtokêsiw , ôtah êh-itinât , êkwah oskâtah ê-wêwakipayihtât , ôtah êkwah êh-âkwaskitinât . The old woman made a leap, and took hold of him here, and threw her legs round him, and clasped him here round the neck with her arms.
êkwah nôtokêsiw wêw-otihtinikêw . The old woman kept a tight hold.
êh-âta-pahkwatinât , nama kaskihêw , osâm ê-maskawisiyit ôhkoma . Though he tried to pull her free, he could not move her; his grandmother was too strong.
papâmôwatêw , mîna awa nôtokêsiw nipiy êh-wêpinahk , êh-sikitât . He carried her about like a pack-load, [no translation]
nêpêwisiw aw oskinîkiw . The youth was ashamed.
êkwah konta papâmohtêw . Then he wandered helplessly about.
itohtêw kisêyiniwa wîkiyihk , itah êh-kêh-pawâmit aw oskinîkiw . He went to the tipi of an old man, a place of which he had dreamt, the youth.
mitoni kisêyiniwiw . He was a very old man.
êy-ati-takohtêt , kâ-pê-wayawiyit . When he arrived, the other came forth from the lodge.
êyahâ ! tânisih k-ôh-pêtôwatâmikawiyin , nôtokêsiw ? itik . “Dear me! Why are you being carried here like a pack, wife?” he asked her.

seg.q:
nâh , ê-pakwâsit awa ,
nôcîhkawin , êh-atiy-itak , êh-pakwâsit ,
ncawâc nka-nayômik , k-ôh-itêyimak .
seg.gloss: “Yah, because this person rejected me when I told him, ‘Woo me!’ Because he rejected me, is why I thought, ‘Then let him at least carry me on his back.’

seg.q: nêki kikosâkak , êwakonik ê-mâh-miyosicik , nam âwiyak npakwâtik .
seg.gloss: Those fellow-husbands of yours, handsome as they are, every one, none of them refused me.
Do not argue with me.
This person has angered me by refusing me.”

seg.q: hêy ê êy , wêskinîkiyan ! ôtêh sâkahikaniwiw .
seg.gloss: “Alas, young man! there is a lake close by here.
You had better go there.

seg.q: êkotêh anih ayâwak nîso nôsisiminânak , ê-kitimâkêyimât awa kâ-nayômat .
seg.gloss: For there stay two of our grandchildren, whom she you are carrying indulges.

p.seg: niy âni wiya nikostâw niwîkimâkan , itwêyiwa . But as for me, I fear my wife,” said the old man.
sipwêhtôwatêw . He went off with his pack.
tâpwêh otihtam sâkahikan , kontah kâ-pêh-pâhpiyit oskinîkiskwêwa nîso . Really, he came to a lake, and there came two young women, laughing gaily.

seg.q: hêy , tânisih mâka mîna k-ôh-awâsisîhkâsoyin , kâ-pê-nayômikawiyan ?
seg.gloss: “Hey, why are you again acting like a child, being carried here on someone's back?”
“Oh, do not reason with me, my grandchildren!

seg.q:
ê-pakwâsit awa , ê-kisiwâhit ,
ncawâc nika-papâ-nayômik , k-êtêyimak .
seg.gloss: When this person rejected me and angered me, I decided, ‘Then at least let him carry me round on his back’.”

p.seg: itah nêpâcih , têpiskâyiki , kêyâpic nayômêw ; kikôwatêsin . Wherever he slept of nights, still he had her on his shoulders; he lay with his pack.
êkosi nama nântaw itwêwak ôk ôskinîkiskwêwak . So those young women said nothing.
ncawâc mahtih npawâmôwinihk nk-êtohtahâw , itêyihtam . “I shall have to take her to my dream-guardians,” he thought.
êkwah papây-itôwatêw . So he carried her round to these places.

têkohtêci opawâkanah ,
êhêhêy , nôsisê , nikostâw ! itâw . Whenever he reached a dream-guardian of his, “Alas, grandson, I fear her!” he would be told.
nama nântaw kîh-tôtâmâwa ta-pahkwatinimiht . Nothing could be done to her, to shake her loose.
êkosi piyis kahkiyaw opawâmôwinihk nama kêkway . At last he had gone to all his dream-guardians without avail.
êkwah ayâw . So there he was.
pikw êkwah ta-nipahit , ta-nipahâhkatosoyân , itêyihtam . “There is nothing in sight but that she will kill me, that I starve to death,” he thought.
kêtahtawê ay-êtataw takosin itah êtohtêci . Then in time he would scarcely reach any place for which he was bound.
piyisk otisinâkwaniyiw itah kâh-nipâci , ê-na-nayômât nôtokêwa . At last, what a sight it was, when he slept anywhere, as he kept carrying the old woman on his back!
kîtahtawê wâpahtam sîpîsis , êw-otâkosiniyik , amiskwa ê-kîh-kipahamiyit . Then at one time he saw a brook, towards evening, a brook which beavers had dammed.
êkotah itohtêw . He went there.
nêtê akâmihk wâpahtam ahkâpaskwah êh-ayâyikih ; Over on yonder bank he saw some water-weeds; LB on {ahkâpaskwah}: A water-weed, not identified. I do not understand this passage.
âspîs mistikwah êh-oyâskwaniyikih ayâyiwa . here and there were sticks of wood that had been shaped.

seg.gloss: “Oh, I shall go lie on yonder bank.

p.seg: kiyâm êkotê nka-nipin , itêyihtam . I may as well die over there,” he thought.

pôtih êtataw pîcitisin . He found that he could barely move as he lay. LB: If the record is right, the word is analysable as initial stem {pîcit-}: “draw toward one”; connective {-i-}; animate finale {-sin}: “come down, lie”; one would expect {ts} for the {t}. Meaning?

seg.gloss: “I had better crawl.

p.seg: ôhcitaw ôma niwîh-nipahik awa nôtokêsiw , itêyihtam . It is plain that his old woman means to kill me,” he thought.
kîtahtawê ati-sipwêhtêw . Presently he started.
nahisin sisonê kipahikanihk . He lay down by the side of the dam.
âsay tipiskâyiw . It was dark now.
ati-pimitâcimôw . He kept crawling.
kêkâc êh-kapât , nôhtêsin . When he had almost reached the bank, he could go no farther.
âh , wâpahkih nik-ôtihtên , itêyihtam . “Oh, tomorrow I shall get there,” he thought.
pakamâkan êh-pêh-tahkonamiyit , kontah kâ-câ-cîpipayit ôhi kâ-nayômât . as he came, carrying a club in his hand, she whom he was carrying on his back, suddenly began to wriggle and squirm.
ncawâc âstam , nîstâh ! itwêw awa kâ-nayômât nôtokêsiwa . “Pray do come here, brother-in-law!” said he who was carrying the old woman.
êkosi pêy-itohtêw . He came.
kiskêyihtam êh-kostâyit êyakonih . He knew that she feared this person.

seg.q: yâh , tânisi ôma , nistâh , k-ôh-nayômat awa nôtokêsiw ?
seg.gloss: “Ho, how is it, brother-in-law, that you carry this old woman on your back?”
“Alas, brother-in-law! Do try to free me!”

seg.q: â , nista ! piko mâka kita-pakamahwak , êkâ wî-pakitiniski !
seg.gloss: Why, brother-in-law! But all you have to do is club her, if she will not let go of you!”
“Oh, grandchild, take pity on me!
Please let me live!
Your brother-in-law will be engaging in contests again.
I shall give him things to use.
He will defeat people with what I shall give him.

p.seg: kiyâm nka-pimâtisin , nôsisê ! itêw . Please let me live, grandchild!” she said to him.

tâpwêh ,
êyag ! êkâ wiya kakwê-cîsi nîstâw . Accordingly, “Yes! Do not try to deceive my brother-in-law.

seg.gloss: If you try to deceive him, without fail I shall hear it.
Now then, let him go!”

p.seg: pakitinik . She let go of him.

êkosi ,
hâ , nistah ! hâw , ôma mîcih ! itik wîstâwa . Then, “Here, brother-in-law! Eat this!” his brother-in-law said to him.

ôtah otasinîwaciyiw ! itâmihk êkotê nik-âyân ! itwêw . “Here is a place of rocky mountains! Underneath there I shall be!” he cried.
êkwah iyâtah-wâ-kakwê-pîkinikahwât ôh asiniyah , piyisk mêsci-misi-wanâcihtâw otâpacihcikana . Then, though she tried to smash those rocks with her ax, at last she wore out every one of her tools.
hâw , nitêm , pê-sipwêhtê ! itwêw , êh-tâpwêt . “Ho, my dog, come here!” she cried, shouting.
tâpwê kiyipa takosiniyiwa . Truly, quickly it came there.
ntêm , nâhah itâmihk kâ-pimisihk ntawi-nipah ! itêw . “My dog, go kill the one that lies down yonder below!” she told it.
êkwah atim awa asiniyah ati-môwêw . Then that dog went eating the rock.
piyis otihtêw . At last it reached him.

seg.gloss: “Do not tear him to pieces, my dog! Only strangle him!”

p.seg: êkosi tôtam , nipahêw . So it did. It killed him.

êkwah nâhah ayîsiyiniw kâ-kihtimit , osîmah awa êyako , êsah wîstâwa kâ-sipwêhtêyit , omisah piko nîsiwak . Then that lazy man off yonder, this one's younger brother, was all alone with his sister, for it seems that his brother-in-law had gone away.
êkwah nâha misâskwat ayâw êskosit êy-iskwâyik , nanâtohk êy-itasinahikâtêyik . He had a saskatoon stick which was as long as he was tall, with all kinds of designs on it.
ispimihk tahkopisoyiwa mêkwanah pêyak . At the tip a feather was fastened.
êkwah êyako pik ôtinam . Only this he took.
omisah kâmwâtapiyiwa , êh-pîkiskâtâyit osîmiyiwa . His sister was sitting there, moodily, longing for her absent brother.

hâw , nimisê , itwêw ,
mahtih nistês nka-ntonawâw ! itwêw ; “Now, sister,” he said, “suppose I go look for my brother!” he said;

êkwah awa pônih-wêpâpîhkêpayicih ,
êkoyikohk êsa mêsi-wanâcihot nisîm , kik-êtêyihtên , itwêw , êh-wayawît , êh-wêpâpîhkêwêpinât opîhtatwânah . “And when this thing ceases to sway as it hangs, then ‘Now it appears that my brother has gone to destruction,’ you will think,” he said, and went out of the tent, after setting his quiver a-swinging by a push of his hand.
wa-wêpâpîhkêpayiyiwa . It kept swaying as it hung.
sipwêhtêw . He went away.
misâskwacos tahkonam . He held the saskatoon stick in his hand.
ksîkocin , kâ-sipwêhtêt . As soon as he had left, he went with great speed.
êkwah tâpwê otihtêw ostêsah , êh-pimisiniyit , êh-nipiyit . Then really, he reached his elder brother, where he lay dead.
ôhi mîkwanah ômis îsi yâyahwêw , ôm ôhci ômiscikomis . He stroked him, like this, with that feather, with that stick of his.
nstêsê , waniskâh ! itêw . “Brother, arise!” he said to him.
waniskâyiwa . He arose.
êkosi tâpwê pimâtisiw awa kâ-yâyahoht . So he really came back to life, when he had been stroked with the stick.
wîcêwêw ostêsah . He went with his elder brother.
itohtêw . He went there.

ê-takohtêt ,
hâ , nstêsê , kê-wâpahk pê-itohtêhkan , itêw . When he arrived, “Now then, elder brother, tomorrow do you come here,” he told him.
êhag , itik . “Very well,” the other answered him.
êkwah itohtêw ôhih kaw-otihkomiyit , kâ-pê-sâkêwêyit oskinîkiskwêwa . Then he went toward where that Lousy One was, and there from over the hill came the young women.
hêy ! êkotêh ayâh ! itik ; “Hey! Stand still where you are!” they said to him;
awiyak âsiskâkêci , êwakoh kika-wîwin , itâw . “The one who outdistances the other, her you will take to wife,” he was told.
pâpahtâyiwa . They ran toward him.
nam âwiya nakatimâwa ; tâpiskôc takopahtâyiwa . Neither was left behind; at the same time both reached him.
êkwah nîkinâhk itohtêtân ! itik . “Now let us go to our dwelling!” they said to him.
â , tâpwê itohtêwak . So they went there.
hâh , ê-pîhtokêcik , kêyâpic êkosi isinâkosiw aw îskwêsis . There, when they entered, that little girl again looked as she had looked before.

seg.gloss: “Hey, what are you going about seeking, like this?”

p.seg: â , iskwêw êh-ntonawak , ê-wîh-wîcêwak , itwêw . “Oh, the fact is, I am looking for a woman to marry,” he said.

seg.gloss: “Then marry this one here!”

p.seg: kitâpamêw . He looked at her.
osâm otihkomiw , itêw . “She is too lousy,” he said of her.

seg.gloss: “Oho, my children, it must be you he has in mind for himself!

p.seg: kiyawâw onâpêmik ! itik . You take him to husband!” she said of him.
êkwah ê-tipiskâyik , kawisimôw . Then, when night came, he lay down to sleep.
kîskwêhkwasiw aw iskwêsis . That little girl walked in her sleep.

seg.gloss: “Greatly I am longing to work! Much I am longing to work!

p.seg: êtokê ê-kihtimit awiyak kâh-pê-nahâhkapit ! itwêw aw iskwêsis . It seems as if some lazy person has come here to stay as son-in-law!” said the little girl.
sêmâk kîksêpâ sipwêhtêw . In the morning at once he went off.
mitoni kiyipa otihtam ostêsa itah kê-kîh-ohcih-nipahâyit wâkayôsah . Very quickly he came to where his elder brother had found and killed the bear.
êkotah takohtêw . He walked to the spot.
nimosô , kipê-nâtitin , êh-mêtawiyân anohc kâ-kîsikâk ! itêw . “Grandfather, I have come to fetch you, for I am engaging in a contest this day!” he said to it.

seg.q: ahag , nôsisê ! cêskwa nîso nimîstôwanah otinamôhkan .
seg.gloss: “Yes, my grandchild! But first do you take two hairs from round my mouth.
To be sure, I do not think you lacking in power of your own.
Your elder brother was deceived by an unfair stroke.

p.seg:
êkosi mayaw takohtahiyini , sêmâk otêmah ta-nâtisahwêw , otâpacihcikanah
itêw ; Now, as soon as you have brought me there, she will send for her dog, who is an instrument of her power,” it told him;

êkosi ,
hâw , êkwah ! itik . and so, “Very well, come now!” it told him.
pakamahwêw ; nipahêw . He clubbed it; he killed it.
kîwêcitâpêw . He dragged his burden home.
kîksêpâ mitonih takohtahêw . Very early in the morning he arrived with it.
mayaw êh-pîhtokêt macostêham oma pêyak ; pêyak pimiwitâw . As soon as he entered, he threw one of those things into the fire; one he kept on his person.

êkwah êh-pahkwêwisomiht ,
nitawâsimisitik , nâtamok ncîkahikan , nimihkihkwan , nimânihtwiyâsk , nitahkâmasiniy , nisêkipitâkanêyâpiyah , êhtahtikih ntâpacihcikanah . Then, when the game had been skinned for her, “My children, go get my ax, my hide-scraper, my stick for treating hides, my pounding-stone, my thongs for stretching hides, as many as are my tools. LB on {nimânihtwiyâsk}: Some tool; the final is {-âskw-}: “wood, stick”.
êkwah kiya , ntânis , papâ-ntonaw nkosis kstês , itêw ; And you, my daughter, go round and look for my son, your elder brother,” she told them;

piyisk ,
hâw , ntawi-ntom kiya ntêm , itêw otânisa pêyak ; and then, finally, “Now, do you call my dog,” she told one of her daughters;

seg.gloss: “For I do not forget that he said, ‘She is too lousy!’”

p.seg: ayis kisimâw , k-ôh-nâtitisahwât okosisah . For she had been angered by the speech; that was why she was sending for her son.
êkwah êh-pê-takohtêt aw âtim , iskwâhtêmihk ispayihôw awa oskinîkiw . Then, when that dog arrived, the youth threw himself toward the door.
nam êskw ê-sîhkipitimiht ôhi wâkayôsiwâyâna , âsay kâ-pê-takosihk aw âtim . The bearskin had not even been stretched, when the dog arrived.

êkosi êh-pîhtokêt , kontah kâ-pê-patapâyôwêyit , kâ-pê-sasawâpikiyit , tâpiskôc kêkway ê-kostahk . Then, when it came into the tent, though no harm had been done to it, it had its tail between its legs, and cringed as it came, just as though it feared something.
êkwah ômis îtêw awa misaskwacos k-âyât ôhi ; Then He Who Had the Saskatoon Stick spoke of it thus;

ômis îtêw ôhi atimwah :
awa cî ê-mamisiyan ? itêw , ê-sâmahwât ôh atimwah . thus he spoke of that dog: “Is it on this creature that you rely?” he said of that dog, and touched it with the stick.
iyawâpiskipayiw . it crumbled into tiny bits of metal.

ôhi mîna êy-âsastêyikih ,
ôhi cî ê-mamisiyan ? itêw , otâpacihcikaniyiwah akinê êh-atih-sâmahamwât . And of those things that lay there in a pile, “Is it on these things that you rely?” he asked her, and touched her tools one after another with the stick.
êkosi êh-atih-pîkopayiyikih , nama kêkway aw îskwêsis iskohtâwân ; When then, one after another, they fell to pieces, that little girl had nothing left her;
mêscihtâwân tahtoh kâ-mamisît . all the things on which she relied had been destroyed.

seg.gloss: “Well, now I shall hunt your lice.

p.seg: pêyak miskawakih , êkosi kitawâsimisak nika-kîwêhtahâwak , itêw . If I find one, then I shall be permitted to take your daughters home with me,” he said to her.
êhag , itwêw aw îskwêsis . “Very well,” said the little girl.
ê-kitâpamikot , misiwê ohkwâkanihk ihkwah ; When he looked at her, all over her face were lice;
êkwah pisinêy ê-pêy-otihtapiskwêyit , âsay sâmahamwân ostikwân ; then, at the very moment when she sought to lower her head, already her head had been touched with the stick;
nama kî-kotâwiyiwa otihkomah . her lice had no time to disappear.
mânnakisk takwâpiskatahwêw ihkwah . Without mercy he smashed the lice against the stony ground with his long stick.
pikw îtê êtâpicih ihkwah pisisik . wherever he looked, it was full of lice.
kîtahtawê kâ-pakicîtotâkot ihkwah awa miscikos k-âyât . Then suddenly some lice came and settled on Him Who Had the Saskatoon Stick.
êkw ê-kwâhkotêyik êkotah itisinam oma miscikos . At that he pointed his stick toward the blazing fire.

kwahkotêyiw , êkwah ôhi kâ-pakiciyit ihkwah êkotah ômistikomihk kâ-matwêtayêhkasoyit . A flame leaped up on the stick, and the lice that had settled on him were there on the stick, roasting until their bellies burst with a pop.

mêkwâc êkos êh-tôtahk , kîtahtawê kâ-takosihk aw oskinîkiw , wîpac kayahtê kâ-wâpamât okâwiya ê-nôcihimiht otihkomiyiwa . While he was doing all this, in time that young man arrived, and at once saw to his surprise how his mother's lice were being hunted down.

hêy , kêkway ôma ê-kîh-nâtaman , awa kîstâskîs kâ-mêsci-misi-wanâcihtât ntâpacihcikanah ? itik . “Hey, on what errand were you off, while your brother-in-law here was destroying my tools to the very last one?” she called to him.
tâpiskamiyiwa kicohcikanis , êkwah môhyâpiciskânis okicôhcikanisihk êh-tahkopitêyik ; The son wore a little flute round his neck; the flute was tied with a small hide thong with the fur turned out;
êkwah pîwâpiskos êh-apisâsiniyik pêmakâmêskamiyiwa . and a small piece of iron he wore across his shoulder.

êkwah ,
hâh , nêkâ , kitôsâmi-mêscihâwak kitihkomak , Then, “Why, mother, too greatly are you wasting your lice.

seg.gloss: It happens that even if we are not defeated, you are to give them up.

seg.q: ayîs nkî-pê-ntomikawin , ayîsiyiniw ê-kitimâkêyimiht , nîsta êh-wîhtamawak , êkwah êkâ ma-mayaw k-ôh-pê-kîwêyân .
seg.gloss: For I have been called here to be present at the blessing of mortal man, that I too may give him mystic knowledge; and that is why I was so slow about coming home.

p.seg: osâm , nêka , kimaci-nôcihtân , itik okosisah . You have gone too far in your evil pursuits, mother,” her son said to her.
awâsis awa ê-mistatayêt , ê-mosêskatêt , mêstatêw-awâsis awa ; okosisah awa k-ôtihkomit . “He was a pot-bellied child and went naked; Pot-Belly Child was he; he was Lousy One's son.
hâw , nîstah , êkwah mâka niya ! itwêw . “Now then, brother-in-law, now is my turn!” he said.
êkosi pôni-pakiciyiwa ihkwah . Then the lice ceased coming down.
êkosih otinam mohyâpiciskanis . Then he took the little thong with the fur on it.
êkwah êkoyikohk kâ-takosihk awa atimwa kâ-kîh-nipahikot . Then he arrived who had been killed by the dog.

seg.gloss: “Ho, elder brother, stay far behind my back!”

p.seg: êkos isiwêpinam . He flung the thing like this.
nawatahaman ôma , êkosi kê-paskiyawiyan ! itik . “If you catch this on the fly, you have won it from me!” he told him.

iyâta-wâ-kakwê-nawatahwâci kamâmakosa êh-wâpiskisiyit , âskaw nama wâpamêw , kayahtê mâna kisiwâk kâ-pmakociniyit mâna . Though he tried to hit it in the air with his stick, in the form it had taken of a white butterfly, yet from moment to moment he could not see it, and then again, suddenly right close there it would be in the air. CHECK double IC
nka-sâkôcihikoh ! itêyihtam . “He will surely defeat me!” he thought.
kîtahtawê ê-wâpiskâyik om ômiscikomis yâyinam ; wâpiskâyiw . Then presently he rubbed the white part of his stick; it was white.
ôtah ê-pimakociniyit , âkwask itisinam , êkotah akohkêw awa kamâmakos . As the thing flew past, he held it in front of it. There the butterfly clung to it.
otinêw . He took it into his hand.
otinam ; kont itastâw . He took the thing, now lifeless; he laid it down carelessly.
êkwah oma ! itik . “Now try this!” the other said to him.
misâyiw pîwâpisk êh-nôtimâyik . it was a huge round block of iron.
sâkohtâyanih ôma , kê-paskiyawiyan ! itik . “If you can handle this, you have won it from me!” he told him.
êkwah ê-wîh-kakwê-âhtastât , nama kaskihtâw . Then, when he tried to move it from the spot, he could not budge it.
kêtahtawê ê-nayawît , ê-wâ-wâpahtahk oma mistik , kâ-wâpahtahk êh-askihtakwâyik . Presently, as he grew tired, as he looked at that stick, he saw that it turned green.
sâminam ; êkotah ocihcîhk misiwê ayîsihtitâw . He touched it with his hand; he placed it against every part of his hand.
sôskwâc ohpinam tâpiskôc ê-yâhkasiniyik . at once he lifted it up, as though it were light.

seg.q: hê , nîstâh , êkwah mâka kê-mâsihitoyahk , ta-wîcêwâyahkok , ta-ntômâyahkok .
seg.gloss: “Ha, brother-in-law, but now we shall come to grips, and we shall call to us whatever beings are to be on our side.
Whichever of us is beaten shall lose the instruments of his power.
Mohter, are all your implements gone?”
“No.

p.seg: êyâpic aniki opahcâwiyak , itah kita-nîpawiyan , itêw okosisah . There are still those instruments of levitation upon which you may stand,” she told her son. LB on {opahcâwiyak}: Animate plural noun; meaning? The translation is surely wrong. Later in the story it seems that the things, whatever they are, consist of {kâwiyak}: “porcupine quills”.

seg.gloss: “Now then, do you first call those who are to be on your side!”

p.seg: misahci-pêcimêw kiyikaw mohcihk ohci . with his call he brought in great number all manner of beings from the earth.
êkwah awa micâskwacos k-âyât êyako misiw îtê itwahikâkêw kîkaw mohcihk . And He Who Had the Saskatoon Stick pointed in every direction all over the ground.

êkwah owîcêwâkaniwâwa êh-akimâcik , pôtih awa misâskwacos k-âyât pêyak âyiwâkipayiyiwa opawâkanah . Then, when they counted their supporters, it turned out that He Who Had the Saskatoon Stick was by one follower ahead.
itâmihk k-âyâcik askîhk ocapîhkêsîsak ê-wâpiskisiyit , ayiwâkipayiyiwa pêyak êyakoni . Of the spiders that dwell under the ground, a white one of them was the odd one.
êkwah mâsihitôwak wîstâwa , aspin ispimihk ê-yâhkîmohkih ôhi itah kâ-nîpawicik . Then he and his brother-in-law contended, as those things on which they stood stretched up into the air.
kîtahtawê nâh êkwah pîhtatwân mistahi wêpâpihkêpayiw . Then, at this time, that quiver off yonder began to sway greatly.

êkwah nâhah ,
êkwah êsah nisîm miyêtawêt ! itêyihtam ; And yonder woman thought, “Now, it appears, my brother is contending!

seg.gloss: However, by all means he has spirit power;

p.seg: kahkiyaw kêkway kîh-wîhtamawâw , itêyihtam . all manner of mystic knowledge has been communicated to him,” she thought.

kêtahtawê ,
nêkâ , niwi-sâkohik . Presently, “Mother, he is about to defeat me.

seg.gloss: Have you used it all up?”

p.seg: namoya ninayawîn , itwêw awa k-ôtihkomit iskwêsis . “I am not yet weary,” said the little girl, Lousy One.

seg.gloss: “Then bring me what you have! Let me stand on it.”

p.seg: namoya êkotôwahk , nkosis ! itwêw . “It is not of that kind, my son!” she said.

mistikwak êskosicik , êkoyikohk êh-pêy-âyâcik , kâw-otinahk opîway awa k-ôtihkomit , ômatôwihk wahcîhk êh-otinahk . They were aloft now at the height of the trees, when the Lousy One took one of the hairs from here, on her body. LB on {wahcîhk}: As {pîway} is “body-hair” this word is probably “armpit” or “pubes.” It is evidently a dependent noun, i.e., one which always has a possessive prefix.
pakamaham oma miscikos . With it she struck that stick.
nama kêh-yahkîmôw . It could no longer grow in length.
êkwah nâha pwâstawâc wêpâpihkêpayiw . Then that thing off yonder barely swayed a bit as it hung.

hêy , oskac ê-pawâmiyân , ocapîhkêsîs , misiwê kîsikohk askîhk ta-papâmâpêkamôwa kipîsâkanâpîma ! itêw . “Hey, as first I dreamt, spider, everywhere in the sky and on the earth, your strings would be tied about!” he cried.
mâkohâw êkwah . He was now being close pressed.
hâ , papâmâmôw êkwah , êh-nawaswâtiht . He fled about, and was pursued.
êkwah nâh îskwêw pêhpêkahâkan ayâw , êkwah êy-âpisâsiniyik ahkâmasinîs . And that woman off yonder had a stone mallet encased in leather and a small pestle-stone.

pakamaham . She struck them. With them she beat something. [no Cree] LB: Out of construction; he should have said {kik-âpacihimâwa}, since the object is obviative. Similarly, though {ôhi}: “these” is plural, only one of the objects, the iron, is mentioned, the thong omitted. KR: Evidently the book is missing a Cree sentence, referred to in the note and appearing in the translation.
piyisk pîwâpisk tâpiskôc êh-âti-misâyik , têhcikâpawiw . At last, when, like iron, it widened out, she stood on it.

seg.q: oskac êh-pawâmiyân , nêyêwac ta-pimakocihk , ta-sipwêhtahit awa kâ-mâkohât nisîma !
seg.gloss: “At first I dreamt, through the air he is to fly, and to take me hence, he who presses close upon my brother!
It was the like of him, after all, that gave me mystic knowledge!

p.seg: êkwah niwîkimâkan opakamâkan kit-ôh-pasastêhwak awa kâ-têhcikâpawiyân , itwêw . And let it be with my husband's war-club that I strike this being on which I stand, that it may speed fast through the air!” she spoke.
pakamaham . She beat it.
itêh nisîm omiscikomis k-âyâyik , êkotê itohtahin ! itwêw . “There where is my brother's stick, thither take me!” she said.
pimakocin . She sped through the air.
mêkwâc namoya kwayask ihtiw ; [no translation]
otâsiyâniw aw îskwêw , êw-otihtât osîma . [no translation]
hêy , otihkomiw-iskwêw ! mêstatêw kâ-nayawihât nisîmah nikitimâkêyimimâh ! itwêw . “Hey, Lousy-Woman! Do not forget that I love my brother whom Pot-Belly is tiring!” she cried.
âpihkonêw otâsiyâna ; pasastêhwêw ôhi kâwiyah . [no translation] with it she beat those porcupine quills.
mêstatêw-awâsis pahkisin , ôki mina kâwiyak . Pot-Belly Child fell to the ground, and so did those quills.

seg.gloss: “Ho, brother-in-law, you have won from me my implements.
Again some time you will be engaging in a contest.

seg.q: êwakonih nikâwiy otihkomah êyakoni kik-âpacihâw , êkwah ôhi pîwâpisk .
seg.gloss: These, my mother's lice you will have for your use, and also these things, the iron and the other.
As the warm weather comes on, well on into summer, that is when you will be contending.”

p.seg: êkosi kîwêwak . Thereupon they went home.
takosinwak wîkiwâhk . They came to where they dwelt.
hâ , êkwah wâwîs mistahi manitôwiw ! itêyihtam awa nôtokêwa kâ-kih-nayômât . “Ha, now he is more of a manitou than ever!” thought He Who Had Carried the Old Woman on His Back.

êkos ê-nîpiniyik , kêkâc êkwah wîstâwa ta-takosiniyit , kîtahtawêh ê-picicik , itêh ê-kapêsicik , Then, when summer came and it was almost time for his brother-in-law to arrive, then at one time, as they moved camp and were stopping for the night,

kîtahtawê kâ-pê-sâkêwêyit ayîsiyiniwah mitoni êh-kawâhkatosoyit , miscikos k-âyât , nâh-nâway kâ-tahkopitêyikih ê-kas-kipitêyikih , êkwah awa kayahtê miscikos k-âyât . there came into sight a very lean man carrying a stick to which at intervals covered-up bundles were tied; they were surprised that this person, too, carried a stick.

êkwah êh-pê-takosihk ,
tawâw ! itâw . Then, as he came to where they were, “Come in!” they said to him.

êkwah ,
â , tânisi ôma ? tântê êw-ohtohtêyin ! itêw aw ostêsimâw . Then, “Why, what is this? Whence do you come?” the elder brother asked him.

seg.gloss: “From the willow-wood.”
“But whence?”
“From the willow-wood, I say!”
“And what are you seeking, as you go about?”
“I have come to take a wife.
Which of the women sitting here is your sister?
seg.note: LB: Literally, “In which place is this one who sits your sister?” - there being three seated women. Questions of identity are often put in this form.

seg.gloss: For your brother-in-law leads you too much of a chase, always going away.”
“You cannot have her to wife.”

seg.q: ôtah nisîmak kisiwâk pêy-âyâwak , kiyawâ mîna êyakonik ta-wîwiyêk .
seg.gloss: “My younger sisters have come with me and are staying close by here, so you may marry them in return.”

p.seg: hâ , nama tâpwêhtamwak . They did not accept this offer.
ncawâc kika-mêtawânânaw ! itwêw awa kâ-kawâhkatosot êwako . “Then we shall have to settle it by a contest!” said the lean one.
hâw , kiya nîkân ! itâw awa ihkwah k-âyâwât . “Very well, you first! he was told who had the lice.
kiyâm mamitonêyihtam , ihkwah ta-pakiciyit . He merely fixed his thought on the idea that lice were to come down.
pakicîtotâk awa kâ-kawâhkatosot . They came down and settled on the lean man.

ncawâc kwâhkotêhk itisinam ôma miscikos kâ-tahkonahk , êkwah ê-kîsisocik ôk îhkwak , nanâtohk maci-pisiskiwak , môhtêwak , ayîkisak , êyakonih êh-otihkomit awa . He pointed the stick which he was carrying toward the blazing fire, and the lice burned up, all the different evil animals, such as worms and toads, which he had as lice.
êkosi kêkâc ê-mêscihimiht , pôyôw . So when they had been almot all destroyed, he quit.
êkwah ôma mohyâpiciskân ; sêmâk ômis îsiwêpinam ; akohkêw êkotah . Then he tried the string with fur on it. At once he moved his stick like this, and there, the thing clung to it.
sêmâk awa kâ-kawâhkatosot otinam pêyak ocihcîhk , ê-sinikonahk ôma pîwâpisk ; at once the lean man took it up into one of his hands and rubbed it;
nêtê êh-isiwêpinahk , kiy-apisâsiniyiw . when he threw it back yonder, it was small again.
êkwah awa ntomêwak kit-owîcêwâkanicik . Then they summoned those who were to be their followers.

pôtih awa kayahtê k-âyât misâskwacos pêyak ayiwâkipayiyiwa , itâmihk askîhk k-âyâcik môhcêsah ê-wâpiskisiyit . It turned out that he who had surprised them by also having a saskatoon stick had one follower more, a white worm of those that stay under the ground.

êkotêh êcik ânih kiy-êtâmoyân , kiy-êtâmoyâhk ! êh-itêyihtahk , kîtahtawê pah-kisimohk êkotê ,
hêêy , nîstâh , tawayâk ! nakatamok kimistikomiwâwa ! niwîh-takohtân ! Then, just as he was thinking, “And so I must flee; we must flee!” suddenly from the west came the call, “Hey, brother-in-law, make room! Let go your sticks! I am coming!” CHECK anih, kiy (related to E dialect kiyi ‘[future]’?)
kêkway êtokê kâ-pêtôwêkotêyik , kâ-pahkihtihk ôma kaskipicêsah , kâ-tahkopitêyikih êwako . Then something came a-flying with noise, and down fell the little bundles that were tied fast to that stick.
pahkihtin mohcihk . It fell to the ground.

êkwah ôma kêyâpic cimatêw oma miscikos , kâ-pê-takosihk , hâw , awa kâ-namahcît , ka-mohyâpitasêkot . And that stick stood upright in the ground again, when he arrived, none other than that awkward man, who wore his garments with the fur turned out.

seg.gloss: “In time to come, mortal man will take up this root.
‘Medicine,’ he will call it, with which my brother-in-law has blessed him in the hither course of time.

seg.q:
êkwah ômah , nîstâw k-âyât ayîsiyiniw ,
misâskwat , nîpisis , t-êsiyîhkâtam , t-ôh-pimâcihot .
seg.gloss: And this which my brother-in-law has here, mortal man will call ‘saskatoon willow,’ and with it will preserve his life.
Now then, go home, my brother-in-law.
Go to the land of mortals.
Do not act wantonly.

p.seg: êkâ wiya nipahtâkêh , itik wîstâwa ; Do not kill,” his brother-in-law said to him;

seg.gloss: “And as for you, who have come here to engage in contest, go to the wooded country of the north.

seg.q: êkwah kisîmak iskwêwak ôtêh âpihtâ-kîsikâhk kit-êsi-sipwêhtêwak .
seg.gloss: And let your sisters set out toward the south.

p.seg: osâm tahkih kiwîh-papâ-mêtawân , êh-oyasowêhk ta-miywâsik askiy , ayîsiyiniw ta-sâkaskinêt askîhk , itwêw ; For you are ever too eager to engage in contests, now that it has been arranged that the earth is to be good, so that man may be plentiful upon earth,” he said;

seg.gloss: “And as for me, I shall return here to the ground.
All mortal men shall take pity on me and on my wife.

seg.q: êkwah kiya , nîstâh , âpakosîsak kâ-kinwâyowêcik kik-êkotôwiwin .
seg.gloss: And you, my brother-in-law, the long-tailed mice, of these you shall be.

seg.q:
êkwah niya ,
ciposcowiyâkanisîs , k-êtwêcik ayîsiyiniwak , êkotôwahk niya !
seg.gloss: And I, those whom men call ‘sharp-nosed mice,’ such a one I shall be!”

p.seg: kîpipayihôw ; âpakosîsiwiw owîkimâkana kikih ; mitoni apisîsisiwak . He threw himself down; he turned into a mouse, and so did his wife; they were very tiny.
êkoyikohk êskwâk âtayôhkêwin . That is the end of the sacred story.
